## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 915, 94]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that \(2^{4n} + 31^n - 2\) is divisible by 15 for all positive integers \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 84, 99, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Use standard results from the List of formulae (MF19) to find \(\sum_{r = 1}^{n}\left(1 - r - r^2\right)\) in terms of \(n\), simplifying your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 100, 917, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 526, 96]]<|/det|>
The equation \(x^{4} - 2x^{3} - 1 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma , \delta\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 103, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
Find a quartic equation whose roots are \(\alpha^{3}, \beta^{3}, \gamma^{3}, \delta^{3}\) and state the value of \(\alpha^{3} + \beta^{3} + \gamma^{3} + \delta^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 122, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents the sequence of two transformations in the \(x\text{-} y\) plane given by a rotation of \(60^{\circ}\) anticlockwise about the origin followed by a one-way stretch in the \(x\text{-}\) direction, scale factor \(d\) \((d\neq 0)\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 326, 135]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathbf{M}\) in terms of \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 599, 181, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 599, 883, 620]]<|/det|>
The unit square in the \(x\text{-}y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto a parallelogram of area \(\frac{1}{2} d^2\) units\(^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 629, 292, 648]]<|/det|>
Show that \(d = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 629, 920, 648]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 435, 114]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{N}\) is such that \(\mathbf{MN} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 220, 138]]<|/det|>
Find N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 917, 420]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 146, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x\text{-} y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{MN}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 336, 88]]<|/det|>
Let \(t\) be a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
The line \(l_{1}\) passes through the point with position vector \(t\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j}\) and is parallel to the vector \(- 2\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j}\). The line \(l_{2}\) passes through the point with position vector \(\mathbf{j} + t\mathbf{k}\) and is parallel to the vector \(- 2\mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 672, 166]]<|/det|>
It is given that the shortest distance between the lines \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\) is \(\sqrt{21}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 144, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 306, 198]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 740, 479, 761]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{1}\) contains \(l_{1}\) and is parallel to \(l_{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 769, 144, 787]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 769, 782, 787]]<|/det|>
Write down an equation of \(\varPi_{1}\) , giving your answer in the form \(\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{a} + \lambda \mathbf{b} + \mu \mathbf{c}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 769, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 546, 92]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{2}\) has Cartesian equation \(5x - 6y + 7z = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 475, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(l_{2}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 186, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 504, 485, 523]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(\varPi_{1}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 443, 103]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{x^{2} + x + 9}{x + 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 113, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 487, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 511, 186, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 512, 547, 532]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 512, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 682, 89]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 69, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 472, 143, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 463, 920, 500]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{x^{2} + x + 9}{x + 1}\right|\) and find the set of values of \(x\) for which

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 501, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
\[2\big|x^{2} + x + 9\big| > 13\big|x + 1\big|. \quad [5]\]
